original_data.question:
A 10-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of high-grade fever, myalgia, and generalized fatigue for 3 days. She returned from a vacation to northern Brazil 4 days ago. She took the appropriate medications and immunizations prior to her visit. There is no family history of serious illness. She appears ill. Her temperature is 39.4°C (103°F), pulse is 110/min and blood pressure is 94/54 mm Hg. Examination shows jaundice of the conjunctivae and skin. The abdomen is soft and nontender; the spleen is palpated 2 to 3 cm below the left costal margin. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 10.1 g/dL
Leukocyte count 4,650/mm3
Platelet count 200,000/mm3
Serum
Glucose 56 mg/dL
Creatinine 0.8 mg/dL
Bilirubin
Total 4.7 mg/dL
Direct 0.9 mg/dL
Lactate dehydrogenase 212 U/L
Which of the following is the most likely to confirm the diagnosis?"

model_response:
This patient presents with fever, myalgia, fatigue, jaundice, and splenomegaly. The leukocyte count is normal, but the platelet count is depressed. The direct antiglobulin test (direct Coombs test) is positive in patients with hemolytic anemia caused by autoantibodies. The patient has a positive direct Coombs test and is therefore at risk for autoimmune hemolytic anemia. The positive direct Coombs test indicates that the hemolysis is caused by autoantibodies. The thick and thin blood smears would show fragmented red cells (schistocytes) in hemolytic anemia caused by mechanical trauma to red cells (microangiopathic hemolytic anemia). The sickle cell test is used to diagnose sickle cell disease, which is unlikely in this patient because of the positive direct Coombs test. The ultrasound of the abdomen would be helpful in diagnosing splenic enlargement, but the spleen is palpable in this patient, so an ultrasound is not necessary.

###Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
Body temperature of 104 degrees Fahrenheit (40 degrees Celsius) or higher.
Painful sensation in the muscles.
The time for Earth to make a complete rotation on its axis; ordinarily divided into twenty-four hours, equal to 86 400 seconds. This also refers to a specific day.
Leisure time away from work devoted to rest or pleasure.
One of the four primary cardinal directions. It is at 0 degree on a compass card. It is the direction to the left of sunrise.
The time for Earth to make a complete rotation on its axis; ordinarily divided into twenty-four hours, equal to 86 400 seconds. This also refers to a specific day.
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.

Deliberate stimulation of the host's immune response. ACTIVE IMMUNIZATION involves administration of ANTIGENS or IMMUNOLOGIC ADJUVANTS. PASSIVE IMMUNIZATION involves administration of IMMUNE SERA or LYMPHOCYTES or their extracts (e.g., transfer factor, immune RNA) or transplantation of immunocompetent cell producing tissue (thymus or bone marrow).
The act of going to see some person or place or thing; it can cover a short or long period but refers to a non-permanent arrangement.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and disease events of blood relatives. A patient's family medical history may be important in diagnosing existing conditions.
A state of ill health, bodily malfunction, or discomfort.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
The mucous membrane that covers the posterior surface of the eyelids and the anterior pericorneal surface of the eyeball.
That portion of the body that lies between the THORAX and the PELVIS.
Lacking in hardness relatively or comparatively.
An encapsulated lymphatic organ through which venous blood filters.
A quantitative measurement of the amount of glucose present in a sample of serum.
A bile pigment that is a degradation product of HEME.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.
